docs.lead_paragraph: CERTAIN kinds of numbers are so seductive that we wolf them down like salted peanuts. Batting averages, stock prices, vote tallies, accident deaths: we want them correct to the last decimal place, because our instincts tell us that precision is the soul of truth. The essayist Will Cuppy caught the flavor of that notion in his criticism of a historian who had rounded off the number of elephants in Hannibal's army to ''about 40.'' Wrote Cuppy: ''Elephants do not come in round numbers. You have one elephant, or three, or 37. Is that clear, Professor?''
